data.title: Comprehensive Guide to Setting Up Domain Admin Account, Routing, DHCP Server, and User Management in a Windows Domain
data.meta_description: In any Windows domain environment, setting up crucial components like a dedicated domain admin account, routing, DHCP server, and user management is essential for efficient network operation and…
data.text:
Brian AbdulMalik

·

Follow

14 min read

·

May 23, 2024

--

In any Windows domain environment, setting up crucial components like a dedicated domain admin account, routing, DHCP server, and user management is essential for efficient network operation and security. This comprehensive guide will walk you through each step of the process, ensuring a smooth setup and configuration.

1. Creating a Dedicated Domain Admin Account:

Log in to the Windows Server using an existing admin account with sufficient privileges.

Open “Active Directory Users and Computers” from the Administrative Tools menu.

Create a new Organizational Unit to put the admin account in, name it _ADMINS

Navigate to the “_ADMINS” folder, right-click, and select “New” > “User”.

Enter the required information for the new user, ensuring to select “Domain Admins” as the primary group.

Follow the prompts to complete the user creation process, setting a strong password and any additional required attributes.

Navigate to the “Member of” tab, click on the “Add” button, and verify the presence of Domain Admins.

2. Setting Up Routing and Remoting Access (Installing RAS/NAT):

This functions similarly to Remote Access Service and Network Address Translation (NAT). Its objective is to enable our Windows 10 client to reside within a private network while retaining the ability to connect to the internet via the Domain Controller.

Open “Server Manager” from the taskbar.

Click on “Manage” > “Add Roles and Features”.

Select “Remote Access” from the list of server roles and follow the wizard to install.

Once installed, configure the Network Address Translation (NAT) component to enable routing between the internal network and external networks.

Follow the prompts to complete the NAT setup, ensuring to specify the internal and external network interfaces and IP address ranges.

3. Setting Up DHCP Server on the Domain:

Open “Server Manager” and select “Add Roles and Features”.

Choose “DHCP Server” from the list and install the role.

After installation, open the DHCP management console from Administrative Tools.

Configure the DHCP scope, including IP address range, subnet mask, default gateway, DNS servers, and any other required options.

Activate the DHCP server to begin leasing IP addresses to client devices on the network.

4. Adding Users with a PowerShell script

# ----- Edit these Variables for your own Use Case ----- #

$PASSWORD_FOR_USERS = "Password1"

$NUMBER_OF_ACCOUNTS_TO_CREATE = 10000

# ------------------------------------------------------ #

Function generate-random-name() {

$consonants = @('b','c','d','f','g','h','j','k','l','m','n','p','q','r','s','t','v','w','x','z')

$vowels = @('a','e','i','o','u','y')

$nameLength = Get-Random -Minimum 3 -Maximum 7

$count = 0

$name = ""

while ($count -lt $nameLength) {

if ($($count % 2) -eq 0) {

$name += $consonants[$(Get-Random -Minimum 0 -Maximum $($consonants.Count - 1))]

}

else {

$name += $vowels[$(Get-Random -Minimum 0 -Maximum $($vowels.Count - 1))]

}

$count++

}

return $name

}

$count = 1

while ($count -lt $NUMBER_OF_ACCOUNTS_TO_CREATE) {

$fisrtName = generate-random-name

$lastName = generate-random-name

$username = $fisrtName + '.' + $lastName

$password = ConvertTo-SecureString $PASSWORD_FOR_USERS -AsPlainText -Force

Write-Host "Creating user: $($username)" -BackgroundColor Black -ForegroundColor Cyan

New-AdUser -AccountPassword $password `

-GivenName $firstName `

-Surname $lastName `

-DisplayName $username `

-Name $username `

-EmployeeID $username `

-PasswordNeverExpires $true `

-Path "ou=_EMPLOYEES,$(([ADSI]`"").distinguishedName)" `

-Enabled $true

$count++

}

If you currently possess a list of names utilizing the script provided below. Save the list of names in the same location as the script.

# ----- Edit these Variables for your own Use Case ----- #

$PASSWORD_FOR_USERS = "Password1"

$USER_FIRST_LAST_LIST = Get-Content .\names.txt

# ------------------------------------------------------ #

$password = ConvertTo-SecureString $PASSWORD_FOR_USERS -AsPlainText -Force

New-ADOrganizationalUnit -Name _USERS -ProtectedFromAccidentalDeletion $false

foreach ($n in $USER_FIRST_LAST_LIST) {

$first = $n.Split(" ")[0].ToLower()

$last = $n.Split(" ")[1].ToLower()

$username = "$($first.Substring(0,1))$($last)".ToLower()

Write-Host "Creating user: $($username)" -BackgroundColor Black -ForegroundColor Cyan

New-AdUser -AccountPassword $password `

-GivenName $first `

-Surname $last `

-DisplayName $username `

-Name $username `

-EmployeeID $username `

-PasswordNeverExpires $true `

-Path "ou=_USERS,$(([ADSI]`"").distinguishedName)" `

-Enabled $true

}

This script is written in PowerShell and is designed to automate the creation of Active Directory (AD) user accounts based on a list of first and last names provided in a file called “names.txt”. Let’s break down the script step by step:

Variables Definition

$PASSWORD_FOR_USERS: This variable stores the password that will be assigned to all the user accounts being created.

$USER_FIRST_LAST_LIST: This variable reads the content of the file "names.txt" which presumably contains a list of first and last names separated by spaces.

2. Secure Password Creation:

$password: This line converts the plain text password stored in $PASSWORD_FOR_USERS into a secure string object using the ConvertTo-SecureString cmdlet.

3. Creating Organizational Unit (OU):

New-ADOrganizationalUnit: This cmdlet creates a new Organizational Unit (OU) named "_USERS" in the Active Directory. This OU will be used to organize the newly created user accounts. The parameter -ProtectedFromAccidentalDeletion ensures that accidental deletion of this OU is disabled.

4. User Creation Loop:

foreach ($n in $USER_FIRST_LAST_LIST) { ... }: This loop iterates through each line in the "names.txt" file, where each line contains a first name and a last name separated by a space.

6. User Account Creation:

Inside the loop, the script performs the following actions for each name:

It splits the first name and last name from the current line and converts them to lowercase.

It constructs a username by taking the first letter of the first name and appending it to the last name, all in lowercase.

It displays a message indicating the user creation process.

It creates a new AD user using the New-AdUser cmdlet with the following parameters:

-AccountPassword: Specifies the password for the user.

-GivenName and -Surname: Specify the first and last names of the user.

-DisplayName and -Name: Set to the constructed username.

-EmployeeID: Set to the same value as the username.

-PasswordNeverExpires: Specifies that the password should never expire.

-Path: Specifies the location (OU) where the user account should be created. It's set to the "_USERS" OU created earlier.

-Enabled: Specifies whether the user account should be enabled immediately upon creation.

Joining a Client Windows 10 Computer to the Domain:

Follow this article here to create a Windows 10 client virtual machine on VirtualBox. Do not install Home version instead install Pro

set the network adapter to internal network and select the one you created earlier when setting up VirtualBox
